content.question: The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is an antiderivative of the function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals, 3 minus the square root of x squared, plus x, plus 4 times the cosine of x, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><msqrt><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></math>. Which of the following is the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of the location of a local maximum for the graph of <math alttext="y equals, f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></math> ?

topic.text: 5.3: Determining Intervals on Which a Function Is Increasing or Decreasing

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
